docs.lead_paragraph: Relationships are work, I realize, but so is being single, and I became pretty good at it.

headline.main: The Hard-Won Lessons of the Solitary Years
headline.print_headline: The Hard-Won Lessons of the Solitary Years

docs.abstract: Sara Eckel Modern Love column describes her trepidation when, after being single for many years, she moved in with a boyfriend for the first time; notes that living with someone has taught her how to be less selfish and more patient.
docs.snippet: Relationships are work, I realize, but so is being single, and I became pretty good at it.

byline.original: By DAVID BROOKS and GAIL COLLINS

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown is sprinting into the final year of his third term as governor with a series of policy successes and powerful financial backers boosting his all-but-certain run for another term.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a story Jan. 4 about rural health, The Associated Press reported erroneously the number of counties in Florida. The state has 67 counties.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama returns to Washington this weekend eager to test whether a modest budget deal passed in the waning days of 2013 can spark bipartisan momentum on Capitol Hill. As he opens his sixth year in office, he also faces legacy-defining decisions on the future of government surveillance programs and the American-led war in Afghanistan.

headline.main: Obama Eyes Modest Momentum on Capitol Hill in 2014

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. medical providers are seeing only a trickle of patients newly insured under President Barack Obama's healthcare law, as insurers, hospitals and doctors try to work out any hitches in coverage.

headline.main: Early Days of Obamacare Bring Trickle, Not Flood, of Patients

docs.lead_paragraph: For working people making modest wages and struggling with high medical bills from chronic disease, President Barack Obama's health care plan sounds like long-awaited relief. But the promise could go unfulfilled.
